Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and lack of corroborating evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to failure to seek asylum in the US and inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Submitted documents deemed insufficient or unreliable
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to seek asylum during two-year stay in the US
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide credible evidence and explanation for delay
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to credibility assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Subjective fear undermined by delay and lack of action
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or supporting documents alleged

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish refugee status
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Delay in seeking asylum and inconsistent statements
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility assessed under reasonableness; procedural fairness under correctness
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution in Turkey and conscientious objection to military service
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards in refugee determination
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimant failed to justify delays and inconsistencies
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of a question and allowance of judicial review
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and timeliness of asylum application
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to delay and lack of corroborating evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony and submitted documents given little weight
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Two-and-a-half-year stay in the US without seeking asylum
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to apply for asylum promptly in safe third country
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Documents submitted without sufficient independent verification
Crimes.Application_Factor: Subjective fear not supported by objective actions
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation through omission and delayed reporting

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-97
Application_Facts: Mrs. Perez de Gomez claimed political persecution and domestic abuse.
Julio claimed political persecution and opposition to military conscription.
Board found political persecution claims weak and domestic abuse claim unsubstantiated due to inconsistencies and lack of immediate threat.
Claimant_Status: Mrs. Perez de Gomez: Adult female claiming political opinion and domestic abuse
Julio: Minor son claiming political opinion and opposition to conscription
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court appeal following Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence supporting or challenging claims
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration for domestic abuse
Insufficient proof of political activism or targeting
Credibility_Assessment: Claims deemed not credible due to inconsistencies and implausibility
Remedy_Sought: Granting of asylum and permanent residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: Political persecution claims lacked sufficient evidence and credibility.
Domestic abuse did not establish a well-founded fear of persecution under Convention grounds.
Opposition to military conscription not substantiated as a basis for refugee protection.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving credibility and document authenticity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in concluding the applicant submitted fraudulent documents and lacked credibility
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant's refugee claim rejected due to inconsistencies and fraudulent documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found significant discrepancies between PIF, oral testimony, and documents; lack of credibility confirmed
Evidence_Type: Lack of police reports or corroborating evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Submission of fraudulent documents and inconsistent statements
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide consistent information and supporting documentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk upon return
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in personal information, testimony, and documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review; RPD decision upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Letter from Harun Al-Rashid deemed unreliable and potentially fabricated

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual claiming persecution as a victim of terrorist threats
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Claims of ongoing threats from terrorist organizations
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant's psychological condition affecting memory and testimony
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of harm if returned to home country
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted threats based on perceived opposition to terrorist group
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Low, due to inconsistencies and embellishments
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found credibility issues despite mental health considerations

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving failure to report persecution and seek state protection
Crimes.Outcome: Claim rejected due to lack of credible reporting and corroboration
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by terrorists in absence of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law and domestic implementation under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Institutional_Action: RPD assessed credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant under threat from non-state actors
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: RPD found applicant did not demonstrate inability to access state protection
Crimes.Credibility: Found lacking due to omissions, inconsistencies, and embellishments
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Presumed adequate; applicant failed to rebut presumption
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Life and security risk from non-state actors
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Individual targeted due to alleged resistance to terrorist demands

Violation_Type: Failure to meet eligibility criteria for refugee status
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution as an Alevi and conscientious objector; alleged risks from Turkish military; inconsistent explanations and lack of supporting documentation
Claimant_Status: Asylum seeker claiming Convention refugee status
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence related to military service, religious affiliation, and personal statements
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and sufficient evidence to support claims of journalism activity and persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility was found lacking due to inconsistencies and absence of corroboration
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld; refugee status denied
Relief_Sought: Granting of refugee status and protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention refugee and person in need of protection under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The applicant failed to provide credible evidence to substantiate claims of persecution or risk upon return; allegations not supported by record
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether refusal to perform military service constitutes grounds for refugee status or protection under IRPA
Credibility_Assessment: Ozunal failed to prove association with persecuted groups or illegitimate military actions
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, evidence on prison conditions, military service laws
Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on Convention refugee status and person in need of protection
Basis_of_Claim: Conscientious objection, fear of persecution for draft evasion
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Punishment deemed reasonable (up to 3 years), prison conditions acceptable, no link to Convention grounds
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Assessment_Standard: Whether punishment is disproportionate or inhumane, connection to Convention grounds
Legal_Standard: Persecution under international standards, risk to life or cruel treatment
Application_Factor: Nature of military service, motive for refusal, conditions upon return
Decision_Outcome: Not a Convention refugee, no need for protection

Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain immigration benefits
Legal_Issue: Is the decision of the Refugee Protection Division rejecting the applicant's refugee claim reasonable?
Outcome: The applicant’s refugee claim was rejected, and the judicial review application was dismissed.
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant’s testimony contained contradictions with a newspaper article; failure to seek asylum in the U.S. undermined credibility.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Contradictions in testimony, lack of corroborating evidence, failure to seek asylum in the U.S.
Application_Error: Inconsistent statements in testimony and evidence
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring justification, transparency, intelligibility, and defensible outcome
Application_Factor: Credibility of applicant, consistency of narrative, availability of alternative protection (U.S.)
Decision_Outcome: Application for refugee status denied; judicial review dismissed

Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Was the panel's decision to reject the applicant's refugee claim based on credibility findings reasonable?
Outcome: The applicant's request for refugee status was denied, and the judicial review was dismissed.
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s testimony contradicted by newspaper article; failure to seek asylum in the U.S. weakened credibility.
Evidence_Type: Testimony, newspaper article, lack of supporting documentation
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation regarding central events in refugee claim
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in testimony, absence of credible evidence, failure to pursue available asylum options
Application_Error: Providing unverifiable or inconsistent information in support of refugee claim
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring justification, transparency, intelligibility, and defensible outcome
Application_Factor: Truthfulness and plausibility of claim, opportunity for protection elsewhere
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied; judicial review dismissed

Violation_Type: Denial of refugee status based on lack of well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-98
Governing_Law: Canadian refugee law, International Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution in Israel based on religion and nationality; reported incidents include school bullying, stoning, and objections to military service
Residency_Compliance: Compliance with residency requirements not disputed
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Reports of discrimination, personal experiences of harassment, knowledge of available military exemptions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate state inability to protect; minor nature of incidents
Credibility_Assessment: Claims not deemed sufficient to establish a well-founded fear of persecution
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugees and protection under Canadian law
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Refugee Division’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: Discrimination does not equate to persecution; state protection was available; incidents were isolated and addressed by authorities; objections to military service were pre-existing and exemptible
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division, Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee protection criteria
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), principles of persecution under international law
Application_Facts: Mr. Usta fled Turkey due to alleged persecution for his religious beliefs and conscientious objection to military service
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration status upon claim rejection
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, cumulative errors in application of law
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of subjective and objective evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, plausible, and objective evidence supporting persecution claim
Credibility_Assessment: Claim found not credible by the Board
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of discrimination or disproportionate punishment under Turkish law; claim lacked credibility and plausibility
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CAIPS notes deemed trustworthy
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged poor interpretation, improper use of evidence, exclusion of witness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No material error in interpretation; excluded testimony immaterial
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires adequate interpretation and fair hearing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of appeal by IAD upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CAIPS notes appropriately considered
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged poor interpretation, reliance on unaffidavit evidence, exclusion of key witness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Waiver of interpretation objections; excluded testimony immaterial
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to raise interpretation issues promptly
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Additional witness testimony (deemed immaterial or redundant)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires prompt complaints about interpretation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Spouse's visa refusal leading to appeal
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of appeal by IAD upheld

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CAIPS notes found credible and trustworthy
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged poor interpretation, improper reliance on CAIPS notes, exclusion of witness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No material error in interpretation; excluded testimony immaterial
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Administrative tribunals must ensure procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Suspicion of marriage fraud in spouse sponsorship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of appeal by IAD upheld

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the dismissal of Mr. Hudson's election appeal based on reasonable findings?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Significant evidence about irregularities in distribution of goods and money before the election was ignored; spending patterns were misinterpreted.
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to show corrupt practices occurred
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Investigator's report lacked thoroughness and ignored circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Court reviews decisions for reasonableness, considering evidence and procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegations of corrupt practices including vote-buying
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Errors in analysis rendered decision unreasonable
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Distribution of goods and money pre-election, spending patterns
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Judicial review under administrative law principles
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; dismissal set aside
Crimes.Authority: Minister responsible for elections under federal regulations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the dismissal of Hudson's election appeal based on reasonable findings?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient direct evidence found, but court identified errors in analysis of spending and procedural irregularities
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Dismissal overturned due to analytical errors
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Appellant must prove fraudulent practices by credible evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Investigation failed to properly assess circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Minister must investigate appeals and determine if corrupt practices occurred
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Decision dismissed due to flawed investigation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Spending patterns, timing of distributions, procedural deviations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal electoral oversight for First Nations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denial or lack of admission noted
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the decision dismissing Mr. Hudson's appeal reasonable given evidence of misuse of public funds?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence of SNP program goods distribution pre-election ignored; lack of transparency and criteria
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Appellant must demonstrate misuse for electoral benefit
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Investigator misconstrued or overlooked key financial data
Crimes.Legal_Rule: If corrupt practice appears, Minister must report accordingly
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Use of public resources (SNP program) for electoral advantage
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Distribution records under SNP program, timing relative to election
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No adequate justification provided for distribution practices
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, program logs, witness accounts
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; no remittal due to new election
Crimes.Authority: Investigative officer (Mr. Dyck, Ms. Kustra), Minister

Crimes.Application_Facts: Allegations that Chief Stevenson engaged in vote-buying through goods distribution
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied misuse of authority and resources to influence voters
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider circumstantial evidence in investigation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over First Nation elections
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Distribution records, spending patterns, timing of benefits
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct evidence but strong circumstantial indicators ignored
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Investigator underestimated significance of indirect evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; original decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to correct unreasonable decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Investigation failed to properly analyze available evidence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Indigenous Services, appointed investigators

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in affirming the RPD's decision regarding internal flight alternative (IFA)
Evidence_Assessment: Attack was random; IFAs in Mumbai and New Delhi were viable
Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to prove persecution and lack of viable IFA
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA, claimants must prove they face persecution or risk and lack a viable IFA
Outcome_on_Merits: Claims dismissed due to existence of viable IFAs
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of safe areas within India (Mumbai and New Delhi) as IFAs
Defendant_Response: RAD affirmed RPD decision; applicants did not challenge IFA findings
Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to Convention refugee status and need for protection
Authority: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Phillips' chief source of income was farming, allowing him to deduct farm losses under the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Assessment: Time spent on farming, capital committed, profitability, income comparison between farming and teaching
Decision_Outcome: Appeal granted; Mr. Phillips allowed farm loss deductions
Burden_of_Proof: On Mr. Phillips to demonstrate farming was his chief source of income
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Phillips' dedication of time and resources to farming
Legal_Rule: Chief source of income determined by factors including time, capital, and profitability, not solely income
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in appellate review of factual and legal findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Disproportionate weight given to income comparison by initial judge
Key_Evidence_Considered: Time devoted to farming, capital investment in farm, income from teaching vs. farming
Legal_Framework: Canadian Income Tax Act – provisions on farm loss deductions
Defendant_Response: CRA reassessed and denied farm loss deductions
Evidence_Type: Financial records, time logs, operational details of farm activities
Remedy_Requested: Overturn tax reassessment and allow farm loss deductions
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Income Tax Act relating to farm loss deductions and determination of chief source of income
Authority: Appellate court decision overturning initial ruling by Judge Bell

Legal_Issue: Entitlement to protection under s. 56 of the Patent Act for pre-patent purchase of enalapril maleate
Evidence_Assessment: Delmar's certificate of analysis indicating product met specifications
Decision_Outcome: Novopharm entitled to protection under s. 56
Credibility_Factor: Reliability of Delmar's certificate of analysis
Legal_Rule: Section 56 allows use and sale of invention purchased or acquired before patent application becomes public
Grounds_for_Claim: Merck alleged infringement of its patent by Novopharm's sale of enalapril maleate
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of delivery (October 1, 1990), patent issuance date (October 16, 1990), deliverability of product
Defendant_Response: Purchase occurred before patent issuance; entitled to protection under s. 56
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (certificate of analysis), transaction records
Remedy_Requested: Injunction to prohibit sale of enalapril maleate
Outcome: Application dismissed; Novopharm may sell the product without infringing Merck's patent

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Permanent resident with chronic paranoid schizophrenia
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: High probability of re-offending violently due to uncontrolled mental illness
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Long-term residence in Canada, family ties, mental illness
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Ongoing and severe due to untreated mental illness
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support conviction and deportation order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record, psychiatric evaluation, Appeal Division findings
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and accepted by the Appeal Division and reviewing court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Findings not patently unreasonable
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Deportation as consequence of criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, immigration laws on serious criminality

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: High probability of re-offending, pattern of violent behavior
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Mental illness, established ties to Canada

Crimes.Risk_Nature: Persistent due to mental health and criminal history
Crimes.Threat_Source: Perpetrator's criminal conduct and mental condition
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as reasonable by judicial review court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Factual findings not unreasonable
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Deportation following conviction for serious personal injury offense
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Permanent resident with chronic paranoid schizophrenia
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: History of violence, untreated mental illness
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Residency duration, familial connections, mental health challenges

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Deemed credible and rational by reviewing court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Appeal Division's conclusions were reasonable
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Deportation as a result of criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 Charter, principles of fundamental justice, immigration law

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Break and enter with intent to commit an indictable offense
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Intent to commit a serious crime, potential for violence
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Long-standing presence in Canada, mental health issues
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High severity due to intent and associated risks
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Significant risk of future criminal conduct
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Preventive removal justified under public interest
Crimes.Threat_Source: Criminal intent combined with mental instability
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Established through conviction and appellate findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No patently unreasonable findings
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Lawfulness of deportation after serious criminal conduct
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 Charter, Supreme Court precedent on deportation powers

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession for the Purpose of Trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether deportation violates section 7 of the Charter
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed criminal record and mental health context
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show breach of Charter or unreasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's mental illness considered but not determinative
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Deportation lawful if aligned with fundamental justice
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal convictions, mental health status, risk of re-offense
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative immigration law and Charter protections
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged deportation as disproportionate and unjust
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation or declaration of Charter violation
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether process leading to deportation was fair
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Presumed full disclosure in administrative proceedings
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Multiple convictions including drug and violent offenses
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Link between criminal conduct and threat to society
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Criminal record, psychiatric evaluations, administrative findings
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order confirmed

Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter of Rights

Legal_Issue: Whether Orange Cove-Sanger Citrus Association sufficiently demonstrated use of the POM-POM trademark in Canada during the relevant period
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavit and exhibits showing sales; incomplete packaging photos and unclear invoices raised concerns
Burden_of_Proof: On trademark owner to demonstrate use in normal course of trade
Credibility_Factor: Sufficiency and clarity of sales evidence including invoices and product representation
Legal_Rule: Under Section 45, use of mark in association with wares in normal course of trade required to avoid expungement
Grounds_for_Claim: Request for proof of use under Section 45
Outcome_on_Merits: Registrar's decision upheld; sufficient evidence found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sales invoices, affidavit, product labeling and packaging exhibits
Defendant_Response: Argued insufficient evidence due to lack of complete packaging and unclear documentation

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in law or fact in dismissing the refugee claim
Governing_Law: Respect for basic human rights and freedoms under international conventions
Credibility_Assessment: Principal claimant found not credible due to inconsistencies and lack of corroborating evidence
Evidence_Type: Lack of documentary or witness corroboration
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Board's findings
Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness or legal error required to overturn Board decision
Application_Factor: Applicants failed to meet burden of proof for refugee status or need for protection

Legal_Issue: Whether the risk faced by the applicant is personalized or generalized under IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, paragraph 97(1)(b)(ii)
Procedural_Stage: Federal Court review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Assessment: Extortion demands made against the applicant
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate a personalized risk
Legal_Rule: A person is protected if they face a personalized risk not shared by others in their country
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk due to perceived wealth or business ownership in El Salvador
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; risk found to be generalized
Key_Evidence_Considered: Extortion demands, general crime conditions in El Salvador
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Criminality_Severity: Moderate, part of broader pattern of organized crime
Risk_Assessment: High general risk in El Salvador for perceived wealthy individuals
Risk_Nature: Non-personalized, based on status as business owner/perceived wealth
Evidence_Credibility: Not challenged, but context determined risk as generalized
Credibility_Assessment: Credible but insufficient to meet legal threshold

Aggravating_Factors: Ongoing demands, linkage to violent criminal environment
Criminality_Severity: High, within context of systemic extortion in El Salvador
Risk_Assessment: Generalized risk affecting many business owners
Risk_Nature: Based on perceived economic status, not individual targeting
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to show victimization, insufficient for personalized risk

Legal_Issue: Whether applicants can prove irreparable harm to justify a stay of removal
Evidence_Assessment: Business loss and potential U.S. detention were unsubstantiated; no evidence of life-threatening harm upon return
Decision_Outcome: Motion denied, removal order to proceed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to meet burden of proving irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Claims discredited; no credible risk found by Refugee Division and PRRA officer
Legal_Rule: Irreparable harm must be proven, not speculative, and cannot rely solely on discredited claims
Standard_of_Review: Assessment based on prior tribunal decisions and Federal Court review
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk in returning to Turkey, potential harm in the U.S.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Findings of Refugee Division and PRRA officer, lack of evidence on business loss and detention risk
Legal_Framework: Immigration and refugee protection legislation, stay of removal procedures
Authority: Federal Court, Refugee Division, PRRA officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Fraudulent Document Possession under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer's decision to find Mr. Dhatt inadmissible for misrepresentation was reasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Court granted judicial review, quashed the decision, remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Dhatt disclosed the adoption deed, indicating no intent to conceal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 40 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Possession and submission of a fraudulently obtained birth certificate
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Disclosure of adoption through official documents negating intent to misrepresent
Crimes.Application_Error: Focus on fraudulent document rather than material facts and disclosure
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Adoption deed showing non-biological parentage and transparency
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation under Section 40 that induces or could induce error in administration
Crimes.Application_Factor: Submission of document known to be fraudulently obtained but with full contextual disclosure

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Dhatt submitted a fraudulent birth certificate but disclosed adoption via official documents
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to admissibility assessment under immigration law
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Submission of a document obtained fraudulently, without intent to conceal material fact
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider full context including disclosure of adoption
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to assess misrepresentation under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to account for exculpatory evidence (adoption disclosure)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No indication of deceptive intent due to disclosure of true family relationship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer's finding of misrepresentation set aside
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision quashed, matter remitted
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Misrepresentation under Section 40 requiring potential to induce error
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No attempt to conceal adoption; document did not assert biological parenthood

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish nexus to Convention grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Allegations of verbal threats and financial exploitation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but evidence deemed insufficient
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low perceived risk due to available state protection
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of legal frameworks and NGOs in Guyana
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Refugee Convention

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Verbal abuse and threats (no physical harm)
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported elder abuse, no physical injury documented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible allegations but insufficient corroboration on state protection failure
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Moderate personal risk, low systemic risk
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Vulnerability due to age, familial abuse
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Availability of legal remedies and NGOs

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in Guyana
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to seek help from available NGOs or police
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unavailability of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to access available resources undermines claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be clearly unavailable despite legislative frameworks
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to elder abuse
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of legal frameworks, NGO services, localized police indifference
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence on state mechanisms
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question and overturning of decision
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plausible but not substantiated with evidence of systemic failure
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personal financial harm, not rising to persecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA, Criminal Code (theft provisions), Refugee Convention

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant proved lack of state protection
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Allegations credible but insufficient to meet legal burden
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reporting, lack of engagement with state/NGO protections
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to familial elder abuse
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to demonstrate unavailability of state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet burden of proof on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – Board considered all relevant factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to mixed fact and law

Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal erred in dismissing the complaint regarding the use of a retracted reference
Evidence_Assessment: The tribunal found no evidence of unreliability or bias in the retracted reference
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate unreasonable decision-making
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Burke's retracted reference was assessed for reliability and bias
Legal_Rule: The tribunal must determine if the reference is sufficiently familiar with the candidate's work; abuse of authority includes bad faith or personal favoritism
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged abuse of authority due to reliance on a retracted reference
Authority: Attorney General of Canada (named as sole respondent)

Legal_Issue: Whether new evidence can be considered in a Section 56 appeal and if it demonstrates sufficient trademark use to prevent expungement
Governing_Law: Section 45 and Section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Invoices and affidavit showing 16 sales of L'AMADEI-branded clothing, including six to Canadian companies
Decision_Outcome: Expungement decision set aside; trademark registration maintained for specific clothing items
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant (Multi-Wear) to demonstrate use of the trademark within the required period
Credibility_Factor: Affidavit and commercial invoices deemed credible and sufficient
Legal_Rule: Section 45 requires use of trademark in Canada within any three-year period; single genuine transactions may satisfy use requirement
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context of administrative review
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to initially provide evidence of use led to expungement notice
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal allowed; registration upheld for certain goods
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sales invoices, affidavit detailing 16 commercial transactions
Remedy_Requested: Set aside expungement decision, maintain trademark registration
Authority: Canadian Intellectual Property Office (CIPO), Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's determination that adequate state protection exists in Colombia is reasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board considered both favorable and conflicting evidence regarding state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to demonstrate inability or unwillingness to avail themselves of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicants' actions were found inconsistent with genuine fear; lack of reporting to authorities
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – reasonableness standard
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by FARC and insufficient state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected due to adequate state protection despite imperfections
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Government efforts to combat guerrilla groups, availability of protection in Bogota, applicants’ failure to report threats
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board emphasized existence of state mechanisms and applicant credibility issues
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court upheld the Board's decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Targeted threats from organized armed group
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of state protection programs in urban areas like Bogota
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Ongoing human rights violations by FARC but declining state control
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – involving death threats and forced recruitment
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: General risk in rural areas, lower in urban centers with state presence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on refusal to comply with demands
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish lack of state protection due to unreported incidents
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Questioned due to inconsistencies and failure to seek asylum elsewhere
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants’ fear deemed not subjectively genuine
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – Convention refugee criteria

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on intimidation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board’s finding on subjective fear and state protection
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim denial
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board assessed credibility based on lack of police reporting and alternative asylum options
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants did not meet burden to show inability to access state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report threats and bypassing U.S. asylum opportunity undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA requires both subjective and objective components
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC after refusing demands
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to sufficient state protection and credibility concerns
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of engagement with Colombian authorities, possibility of internal relocation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International and domestic refugee law standards
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board cited functional state institutions and applicant inconsistencies
Crimes.Outcome: Board’s decision upheld by Federal Court
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of restricted drugs for the purpose of trafficking
Failure to disclose dependent child under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the IAD commit a reviewable error in dismissing the applicant's appeal based on misrepresentation?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of IAD's Removal Order decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant did not disclose marriage or dependent son during visa application and entry
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD's decision was reasonable and within acceptable outcomes
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Omission found to be intentional and serious
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under IRPA, failure to disclose a dependent child constitutes misrepresentation if it induces an error in immigration processing
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misrepresentation due to non-disclosure of family members
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Non-disclosure of marriage and dependent child
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Outcome: Removal Order upheld
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA - Failure to disclose dependent child

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of IAD's decision on credibility and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the IAD commit a reviewable error under subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Courts Act?
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, Removal Order upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's non-disclosure was found not credible by the IAD
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Visa application records, family status documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose spouse and dependent son leading to erroneous visa issuance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Seriousness of misrepresentation and lack of credibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Permanent resident visa issued erroneously due to incomplete information
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of IAD's factual and credibility findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to IAD decisions

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer correctly applied the test for state protection and procedural fairness
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 97, 112-116
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review after negative PRRA decision
Evidence_Assessment: Officer improperly focused on state efforts rather than results, ignored contradictory evidence, did not adequately consider PIF statements
Decision_Outcome: Negative PRRA decision due to perceived insufficient risk evidence and lack of credible claims
Credibility_Factor: Presumption of truthfulness in Personal Information Form (PIF), credibility of applicant's claims
Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness under IRPA s. 113(b), presumption of truthfulness in PIF
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable assessment, failure to respect procedural fairness, improper reliance on non-state agencies
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer's decision found unreasonable and unjustified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Personal Information Form (PIF), evidence of state protection efforts, reports from non-state agencies
Legal_Framework: IRPA, principles of procedural fairness, standard of review in administrative decisions
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, re-determination by a different officer
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remitted for reassessment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in its sur place claim by making contradictory findings and selectively analyzing evidence?
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court allowed the application for judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility questioned; inconsistencies noted but not fully explained
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, including Amnesty International report
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Sur place refugee claim based on activities after leaving Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: LTTE association and risk upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Application_Error: Selective analysis of evidence and inconsistent findings
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Amnesty International report on country conditions and risks for LTTE-linked individuals
Crimes.Application_Factor: Risk of detention and persecution upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected initially; decision set aside on judicial review
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim involving illegal entry
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to irregular arrival
Crimes.Outcome: Claim rejected by RPD; Federal Court remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived LTTE links
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Initial rejection overturned; case remitted to new panel
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refugee status denied despite documented country risks
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant arriving irregularly via MV Sun Sea
Crimes.Protected_Group: Persons with political opinion or membership in particular social group
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Sri Lankan Tamils perceived as linked to LTTE
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate state protection in Sri Lanka for returned asylum seekers
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Risk of arbitrary detention, torture, or ill-treatment upon return
Crimes.Credibility: Partially accepted but undermined by lack of documentary corroboration
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Found inadequate in general, but not applied consistently to applicant
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious harm including detention and interrogation by Sri Lankan authorities
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Imputed political opinion due to presence on MV Sun Sea and alleged LTTE ties

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 16(1) of IRPA – misrepresentation affecting admissibility
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk due to sur place activities but provided inconsistent testimony
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Sri Lankan national arriving irregularly in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Unauthorized entry and stay pending refugee determination
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged false statements regarding extent of LTTE involvement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess documentary evidence supporting claim
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration and refugee matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, personal testimony, AI documentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient weight given to credible country evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mixed assessment; some elements accepted, others dismissed without rationale
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed; later found unreasonable on judicial review
Crimes.Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by a different panel
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and remittal of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of credible LTTE ties and personal risk

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving organized human smuggling operation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA sections on inadmissibility due to organized criminal activity
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to address key evidence impacting risk assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Public record through judicial review proceedings
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected; decision found unreasonable and remitted
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Arrival in Canada via MV Sun Sea, part of large-scale smuggling operation
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Irregular maritime arrival with 499 other passengers
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No individual criminal charges, but association with smuggling event
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential implication in organized criminal activity under IRPA s. 37
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Risk upon return linked to both state and non-state actors in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Amnesty International, UNHCR, and IRB country reports
Crimes.Outcome: Initial refusal; quashed and remitted by Federal Court
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Lack of credible evidence linking applicant directly to smuggling network
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to justify dismissal of key documentary evidence

Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of breach, including admission by Mr. Falcon
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Falcon admitted to entering the clothing store
Legal_Provision: Subsection 49(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Dispute_Type: Enforcement of financial guarantee due to condition breach

Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonableness; not met
Legal_Rule: Guarantee enforceable upon failure to comply with conditions
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in enforcement without conviction
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside enforcement

Dispute_Type: Enforcement of financial guarantee based on alleged breach
Legal_Provision_Involved: Subsection 49(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was upheld in enforcement
Basis_for_Decision: Breach occurred; no discretion to reduce post-February 1, 2007

Evidence_Sufficiency: Admission by Mr. Falcon, corroborated by evidence

Dispute_Type: Enforcement of $20,000 guarantee following condition breach

Legal_Rule: Failure to comply triggers enforceability of guarantee

Dispute_Type: Enforcement of financial guarantee due to breach

Legal_Issue: Unreasonable assessment of evidence and application of qualitative test for citizenship
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision remanded to the Minister for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about applicant's credibility due to undeclared absences and misrepresentations
Evidence_Type: Absence records, credit card usage, residency indicators
Legal_Provision: Residence requirements under the Citizenship Act (quantitative and qualitative tests)
Basis_of_Claim: Centralized mode of existence and physical presence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Undeclared absences, dual residency, inconsistent financial activity
Application_Error: Failure to rigorously analyze contradictory evidence and justify findings
Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory evidence regarding absences and credit card use
Legal_Standard: Qualitative and quantitative residence requirements for citizenship
Application_Factor: Physical presence, centralized mode of living, financial ties
Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision set aside; matter remanded
Document_Fraud: Potential misrepresentation in application regarding residency and absences

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer's failure to properly consider hardship evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Hardship due to medical condition and lack of support

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a quadriplegic with no family in Jamaica and faces removal after criminal convictions
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer relied on undisclosed internet research without notifying applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Internet research by officer not disclosed to applicant
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider probative evidence about healthcare in Jamaica

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable and procedurally unfair

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low risk due to physical disability
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Minimal threat due to physical limitations

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of family support and medical infrastructure in Jamaica

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond authorized stay

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored direct evidence on care for quadriplegics

Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 25(1) IRPA allows exemptions on H&C grounds
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Severe disability and lack of care in home country
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence of care facilities in Jamaica

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Severe physical disability limiting future risk

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's health condition well-documented
Not challenged
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Conviction led to inadmissibility under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA related to serious criminality (s. 36(1))

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada due to serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 36(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of serious assault, deemed inadmissible, non-removable to Sudan due to danger
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Abuse of process argument raised regarding removal order pursuit despite non-enforceability
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction, inadmissibility report, risk assessment for removal to Sudan
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found by the Board or court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No credibility concerns raised
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of removal order, abuse of process claim
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal, declaration of abuse of process
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard for abuse of process under administrative law and IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Minister acted within legal authority; no malice or improper motive; process followed correctly

Application_Facts: Applicant failed to provide requested educational documentation despite email notification; employment history raised potential misrepresentation concerns.
Residency_Compliance: N/A - application was rejected prior to granting of status
Misrepresentation_Element: Yes - potential misrepresentation related to employment history requiring procedural fairness
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to lack of notice on missing documents
Jurisdictional_Issue: Judicial review of visa officer's decision by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Missing educational documentation leading to insufficient points
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed, but potential misrepresentation noted in employment context
Relief_Sought: Overturn of visa rejection and remittal for reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Visa Officer's decision
Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness as officers are not required to notify applicants of deficiencies unless misrepresentation is suspected; applicant was notified of missing documents but failed to respond adequately
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in concluding that the Applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection under sections 96 and 97 of IRPA?
Evidence_Type: Evidence of institutionalization of Simon Durrant
Availability of state protection in St. Vincent
Basis_of_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution based on past domestic violence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: State protection available in St. Vincent
Application_Factor: Fear of return to St. Vincent due to past abuse
Decision_Outcome: Applicants are neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection

Mitigating_Factors: No police involvement sought by victim
Risk_Assessment: Low risk due to institutionalization and time elapsed
Risk_Nature: Potential future harm if perpetrator released
Evidence_Type: Lack of recent contact or threats
Credibility_Assessment: Board found claim not supported by current evidence

Criminality_Severity: Serious past conduct, but no recent activity
Risk_Type: Risk of future harm upon return
Credibility_Assessment: Board did not find sufficient evidence of ongoing danger

Sub_Crime_Type: Threats by an individual with violent history
Prior_Criminality: History of making threats and violence
Criminality_Severity: High prior severity, low current risk
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish credible ongoing threat
Credibility_Assessment: Claim not supported by current evidence

Crime_Name: Unreasonable delay in processing immigration application
Legal_Provision_Violated: Duty to decide as soon as possible under the Immigration Act
Application_Facts: Applicant filed for permanent residence in 1996; significant delays occurred post-1998 due to CSIS inactivity despite completion of criminal sentence
Evidence_Used: Timeline of application, periods of inactivity, CSIS delays
Remedy_Sought: Order to issue decision by a specified date
Legal_Standard_Applied: Writ of mandamus requires clear duty and lack of alternative remedy
Decision_Rationale: Overall delay was unreasonable, especially due to post-conviction inactivity by CSIS

Prior_Criminality: Applicant had a prior criminal conviction
Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high, involving violent offense
Legal_Provision: Criminal Code - Assault with a weapon

Application_Facts: Applicant must accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application; Mr. Haj-Kamali's absences were miscalculated by up to 136 days
Residency_Compliance: Alleged insufficient physical presence; calculation error and legal test ambiguity identified
Procedural_Issue: Miscalculation of absences, ambiguous application of legal test (physical presence vs. centralized mode of existence)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate calculation of absence days, lack of clarity in interpreting residency
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application due to insufficient residency
Outcome: Remitted to Citizenship Court for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application with correct factual and legal assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – 1,095-day residency requirement
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness (factual findings), Reasonableness simpliciter (mixed fact and law)
Decision_Rationale: Potential factual error in calculating absences and unclear legal standard may have affected outcome

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 691 days; maintained strong ties to Canada including family, property, and frequent returns
Residency_Compliance: No – fell short of 1,095-day requirement; central mode of existence disputed
Procedural_Issue: Misapplication of the Re Koo centralized mode of existence test; factual errors by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, family ties, property ownership, travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient assessment of comparative ties to Canada vs. other countries
Outcome: Case remanded to another Citizenship Judge for re-determination
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of residency based on proper application of law and facts
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of existence test from Re Koo
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual and legal issues; correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Significant factual errors and misapplication of the Re Koo test in assessing residency
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal entry or re-entry into Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Inadmissibility on criminal grounds and failure to comply with departure order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was deported based on a valid conviction for mischief; later acquitted but did not file judicial review within required time frame
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deportee seeking to overturn removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to illegal re-entry after deportation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Late filing of application for judicial review beyond statutory deadline
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration matters under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, acquittal decision, deportation order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of justification for delay in filing judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly assessed; focus on procedural timeliness
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Quashing of deportation order based on subsequent acquittal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and extension of time to file
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of delay and likelihood of success on merits
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Deportation order valid when issued; acquittal does not retroactively invalidate order; delay unjustified

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 36(1) - Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of mischief, deported, later acquitted, challenged deportation order after 15-day review period
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident found inadmissible due to criminal conviction
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain lawful status post-conviction
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to file judicial review within 15 days; request for extension denied
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court’s authority to grant leave for late applications
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction, appellate acquittal, immigration file
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient explanation for delay in filing application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding; issue centered on legal timing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for extension and judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order remains enforceable
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn deportation order based on quashed conviction
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Extension of time to apply for judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Test for granting extension: explanation for delay and merit of claim
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Order lawful at time of issuance; IRPA does not require automatic reversal upon acquittal; delay unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Immigration Appeal Division, Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether a deportation order based on a conviction can stand after the conviction is overturned
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-acquittal judicial review of immigration decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed validity of original conviction and impact of appellate acquittal
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant bore burden to justify delay and show viable legal basis
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not central; legal effect of acquittal was key
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions based on lawful facts at time of decision remain valid despite subsequent changes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Conviction overturned on appeal; argued deportation order should be void
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; no retroactive invalidation of deportation order
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Original trial record, appellate court decision, immigration hearing transcript
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intersection of criminal law and immigration law under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged ongoing validity of deportation after acquittal
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code s. 430(1)(b): Mischief causing damage under $5,000
Crimes.Authority: Provincial Court, Appellate Court, Immigration Tribunal

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 840 days of presence but was 347 days short; days before permanent residency counted as half-days
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day requirement within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient documentation provided to support residency claim
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documentation to substantiate claimed days of residence
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence for at least 1,095 days in the preceding four years
Decision_Rationale: Judge's interpretation and application of residency rules were reasonable and well-explained; no error in rejecting flexible tests due to lack of evidence

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 493 days during the relevant four-year period, resulting in 636 days of physical presence in Canada; strong ties to Canada were not adequately considered
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge applied unclear tests and omitted key factors; insufficient reasoning
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider pre-application residency and strong connections to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Original application denied by Citizenship Judge
Relief_Sought: Overturn of denial and grant of citizenship
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence required within four years prior to application
Decision_Rationale: Judge made errors in law and failed to provide adequate reasons; strong ties to Canada were not properly assessed
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), Federal Court on appeal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Protection under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a victim of abuse by a high-ranking official in Mexico; faces challenges accessing state protection due to abuser's status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board failed to properly assess internal flight alternative (IFA) and personal circumstances
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of state protection within Mexico
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony regarding abuse and lack of police response
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not address specific barriers to accessing protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged on credibility grounds
Crimes.Outcome: Set aside and remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and reassessment by the Board
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board failed to rebut presumption of state protection with clear evidence and neglected personal circumstances in IFA analysis

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on persecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection and viability of internal flight alternative
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA, Ward framework, IFA two-step test
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant’s testimony on abuse and systemic corruption
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to show lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Two-step IFA test must consider personal circumstances
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence by state actor
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Abuser’s high-ranking status, lack of police intervention
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection presumed but not demonstrated as effective
Crimes.Outcome: Case remitted for reassessment

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator’s position of power and influence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk of harm if returned
Crimes.Threat_Source: Former intimate partner with state authority
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to relationship with perpetrator
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not questioned

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Official status of perpetrator enabling impunity
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of abuse and unlawful confinement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and plausible account

Application_Facts: Mr. Acharige argued that the PRRA Officer erred in assessing his risk claims; he claimed risks in Sri Lanka due to political involvement and alleged murder ties.
Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal after judicial review application
Evidence_Used: PRRA assessment, RPD findings, applicant's submissions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Arguments found speculative and unsupported by credible evidence
Credibility_Assessment: The RPD and PRRA Officer both concluded Mr. Acharige was not at risk in Sri Lanka; lack of credibility in risk claims
Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal pending resolution of risk claims
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue
Decision_Rationale: Court found arguments speculative and lacking credible evidence; prior decisions found no risk in Sri Lanka
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court (judicial review), PRRA Officer (administrative decision)
